explanation:
SEC_AREA2_URL: The controlling expression compares url against SEC_AREA2_URL (with an empty-string concatenation). You must know the exact macro/string value (and any macro expansions) to determine whether the comparison is against a constant that could make the if-condition invariant.

strcmp: The controlling expression is 0 == strcmp(url, ...). Understanding strcmp's prototype/semantics (that it is a runtime function returning 0 only when the two strings are equal) is required to decide whether the expression can ever be a compile-time/invariant constant or whether it is evaluated at run-time.

handle_sec_areas_req: This function is the direct caller of reply_with_area2_pages. You need its implementation to see what actual value is passed as the url argument (e.g., whether handle_sec_areas_req always passes a fixed/constant string or a request-derived, variable string). If url is always the same constant at all call sites, the controlling expression could be invariant.

ahc_main: This is the caller of handle_sec_areas_req. To fully determine whether url is ever variable at program scope you may need the higher-level request-dispatch logic (ahc_main) to see how requests/URLs are constructed and passed into the handler chain; this helps rule out that url is always a compile-time or global constant (an MISRA violation possibility).
